Effects of perspective elevation and environmental geometry on representation of a virtual room space
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 26 June 2008

Effects of perspective elevation and environmental geometry on representation of a virtual room space

  • Zhiqiang Luo1 &
  • Henry Been-Lirn Duh1 

Virtual Reality volume 13, Article number: 27 (2009) Cite this article

  • 110 Accesses

  • 3 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The present study investigated how perspective elevation and room geometry influenced mental representation of spatial layout in virtual rooms. One virtual rectangular and one virtual cylindrical room were constructed. Subjects observed the spatial layout on the floor from five perspectives along the vertical dimension of each virtual room. Then they judged the direction of objects with respect to egocentric and canonical coordinates. The analysis of spatial judgment indicated that judgment accuracy of vertical direction decreased as the perspective elevated, while global situation awareness was best maintained at the 45° elevation angle. The effect of perspective elevation on judgment of horizontal direction was only found in the rectangular room. Moreover, subjects judged the relative direction between objects more quickly in the cylindrical room than in the rectangular room. Applications of these findings to virtual environment design were discussed.

Introduction

In many virtual worlds, people often need to travel through three-dimensional (3D) simulated buildings to complete tasks, in which navigation is a necessary component. A well-developed mental representation of virtual space is essential to successful navigation performance in virtual environment (Darken et al. 1998). Mental representation refers to the internalized knowledge of the spatial characteristics of an environment and spatial relationships within it (Colle and Reid 2003). Spatial characteristics include the information about the overall layout and individual objects, such as geometrical shapes and locations. Spatial relationships in the representation should be interpreted with respect to spatial frame of reference (McNamara 2003), the means of representing the locations of objects in space (Cognition and Computation 1999). Spatial frame of reference can be categorized into the egocentric and exocentric frames of reference. An egocentric frame of reference is defined with respect to some part of the observer whereas an exocentric frame of reference is external to the observer, such as the canonical coordinates. In order to navigate effectively within a virtual environment, a virtual world participants needs to have both knowledge of the environment with respect to the egocentric reference (“Where am I?”) and knowledge of the goal with respect to the exocentric reference (“Where do I need to go?”).

Most of the previous research (Shelton and McNamara 2001; Colle and Reid 1998) on mental representation of room space was conducted with subjects standing on or walking around the floor of a room. For example, in Shelton and McNamara (2001) study, subjects observed spatial array in a real room from one or several places on the floor and then made judgments of relative directions between objects in spatial array. They found that the judgment of relative directions was more accurate when subjects imagined themselves facing with the same heading as the first view from which they started learning the layout. In a virtual room, however, it was reported that people could remember the relative locations of objects equally well among four quadrants (front, back, right, and left) after walking around the virtual room (Colle and Reid 1998). The perspective from which subjects observed the spatial layout in above studies is called route perspective, the perspective of a floor-level observer within the space. Besides route perspective, people can also observe the space from either oblique or aerial perspective which results from viewpoint elevation. These viewpoints are external to the space: the direction of oblique perspective is oblique to the floor plane and the direction of aerial perspective is vertical to the floor plane. The key question addressed in the present study was how perspective elevation influenced mental representation of a virtual room space.

Spatial learning with perspective elevation

The effect of perspective elevation on spatial learning is observed when a pilot operating an aircraft uses a 3D perspective display for navigation. Different perspectives from which the environment is rendered on a display influence a pilot’s ability to match the features on a display with the forward field of view (FFOV) within the large space (Hickox and Wickens 1999). One reason for this influence is that people misunderstand the features rendered on the 3D perspective display. For example, McGreevy and Ellis (1986) found that when the relative direction was judged in a 3D perspective display, target elevation was consistently overestimated while the azimuth error varied sinusoidally with target azimuth direction and was modulated by the field-of-view angle. Wickens and Prevett (1995) observed that the egocentric viewpoint supported the best guidance, whereas a mid-distance exocentric viewpoint supported the best global situation awareness. Using a navigational checking task, Hickox and Wickens (1999) studied the effect of perspective elevation on map learning: when the map displayed nearly flat terrain images, 90° elevation was nearly as good a map angle as any others; however, when more vertical terrain development was incorporated, 45° elevation appeared to be the optimal elevation angle. Furthermore, Wickens (1999) noted that pilots needed to perform mental transformations when interpreting the information on a 3D display and the mental transformations that occurred along the horizontal and vertical orientations mediated the different reference frames required for specific tasks.

Experimental evidence (Thorndyke and Hayes-Roth 1982; Shelton and McNamara 2004) has also shown that the spatial learning with route and aerial perspectives produce qualitatively different mental representations of space. Thorndyke and Hayes-Roth (1982) found that after studying a building floor plan, which was one way to learn spatial relationships with the aerial perspective, subjects could easily assess the distance and directions between arbitrary locations in the building; in contrast subjects who navigated along a floor inside a structure using the route perspective could easily obtain procedural knowledge about routes between locations. In Shelton and McNamara (2004) study, subjects navigated a virtual floor layout from the route perspective or the aerial perspective. They found that the spatial learning with the route perspective required subjects to make more inferences about the global properties of space, whereas the spatial learning with the aerial perspective provided more information about the environment constraints, such as walls.

Similarly, users can observe a virtual environment from route, oblique or aerial perspective. For instance, a user may stand within the space to obtain an egocentric viewpoint. Alternatively, a user can look at the space from an external viewpoint. Virtual environments that permit the user to fly into and out of the space can provide multiple perspectives and create a flexible single-user environment. In the CALVIN project, Leigh et al. (1996) explored the influence of multiple perspectives on the architectural design of virtual building. They found that users who used the egocentric viewpoint located object position more precisely, whereas users with the exocentric viewpoint took charge of the large movements of objects. Schafer and Bowman (2004) observed that in a virtual room, subjects who were given the egocentric viewpoint learned small details better, while those with the exocentric viewpoint had better understanding of the overall layout. The findings from these two studies suggest that the perspective taken in virtual environments affect the frame of reference acquired in spatial learning.

Representation with different environmental geometries

From a spatial reference point of view, environmental geometry can be understood as an exocentric frame of reference. The normally stationary surroundings can provide information about the position, orientation and movement of an individual in space. Previous studies (Hartley et al. 2004; Werner and Long 2003) demonstrated that environmental geometry has an impact on mental representation of space. For instance, the changes of the wall size can affect how individuals locate the observed cues in the virtual arena (Hartley et al. 2004). Werner and Long (2003) found that changing the shape of room walls led much difficulty to the interpretation of the floor structure. Shelton and McNamara (2001) found that when the room shape was changed from rectangular to cylindrical, the spatial information was still easier to access in the first viewing direction from which subjects started observing the same layout in each room. However, these studies only examined the effect of geometry on mental representation when the space was observed from the route perspective with different orientations, and thus it is necessary to this issue when the space was observed from the aerial or oblique perspective.

The goal of the present study was to examine how perspective elevation and environmental geometry affected the mental representation of a virtual room space. Subjects were required to observe the spatial layout inside the room from five perspectives on the vertical dimension of the virtual room. Mental representation of the virtual room space was indicated by subjects’ performance in spatial tasks following the study of the spatial layout in the virtual room. It was hypothesized that the perspective-dependent representation of virtual room space would be constructed.

To determine the effect of geometry on the representation, the same experimental procedure would be conducted in both a rectangular and a cylindrical room. Based on the findings of previous studies (Colle and Reid 2003; Shelton and McNamara 2001), the rectangular shape provided ecologically valid structural features that affected the learning of spatial relations among objects in the room. Thus, subjects would perform spatial tasks worse in the rectangular room than in the cylindrical room.

Method

Participants

Sixty subjects (30 males and 30 females) aged from 20 to 30, participated in this study. All subjects were students from Beijing Jiaotong University in China and had normal or corrected-to-normal vision. They participated in the experiment for the monetary payment.

Apparatus and materials

A laptop was used to present the virtual room on the i-glass Head Mounted Display (HMD, i-O display Systems, LLC). The HMD provided images at a resolution of 800 × 600 and a 26.5° diagonal field of view (FOV). The virtual room constructed using EON software (EON Reality Company) is shown in Table 1. The rectangular room measured 8 m × 6 m × 6 m in the virtual space, and the virtual cylindrical room had the radius of 4 m and the height of 6 m. Nine objects were selected with the restrictions that they shared no primary semantic associations or similar functions so that subjects would associate each object with its location only to remember the layout in the virtual room.

Design

The geometric field of view (GFOV) was 75°. Subjects could watch the entire spatial layout without rotating the orientation and no objects blocked the view of other objects. Subjects learned the locations of nine objects as shown in Fig. 1. This paradigm was motivated by the work of Shelton and McNamara (2001), but three of the selected objects were higher than the route perspective (the ordinary eye height, 1.7 m). The five viewpoints were located along a 90° arc with a 4-m radius on the vertical plane. The arc center was also the center of the layout but at the level of the route perspective height. The angle increased with the increasing perspective height (see Fig. 2). The 0° viewing angle was the route perspective, while the 90° viewing angle taken at the peak of the arc was the aerial perspective. The other three angles (30°, 45°, and 60°) were the oblique perspectives. Thus, the principal independent variable was the perspective presented by the viewing angle, including 0°, 30°, 45°, 60°, and 90°. After observing the spatial layout, subjects started performing spatial tasks including an egocentric pointing task and a world-referenced task.

The egocentric pointing task was used to assess the self-to-object spatial relation in the memory by retrieving the spatial relations with respect to the egocentric reference (Easton and Sholl 1995). The representation of self-to-object spatial relation is essential to local guidance in space. The world-referenced task was employed to assess the global situation awareness by asking subjects to judge the spatial relations in the context of the canonical coordinate (Wickens and Prevett 1995). High situation awareness requires good understanding of the structure of an environment. The sequence to conduct these two tasks was counterbalanced in this study.

A coordinate system was set up in the test environment for egocentric pointing task (see Fig. 3). The original point of this coordinate system was a mark on the floor which was 1 m in front of a board, the Z axis was defined to be vertical to the floor, the Y axis paralleled the front board, and the X axis was orthogonal to the front board. Therefore, each position in the test environment could be presented by a coordinate (x, y, z) of this system. The instruction, for example “Imagine you are facing object A, please point to the object B”, was displayed on the computer. Subjects were required to use a laser pointer to indicate the direction of the top of the target assigned in the instruction. The experimenter recorded the coordinates of the eye and the projection of the laser pointer on the board. Based on these coordinates, the horizontal and vertical angles of the line from the eye to the projection point in the coordinate system could be computed.

The dependent variables in the egocentric pointing task were the angular error and the pointing latency. The angular error was measured as the absolute angular difference between the pointing direction and the actual direction of the target. After the spatial layout was designed, the coordinate of the top of each object and the coordinate of the viewpoint in this virtual room were determined. Thus, the actual directional angle from the viewpoint to the top of each object could be computed. There were two angular errors: the error of horizontal angle and the error of vertical angle. The pointing latency was measured as the time from the presentation of instruction to the end of the subject’s response, which was recorded using a stop watch.

In the world-referenced task, subjects took a seat in front of the computer display. They were first instructed the “North” direction in the virtual room. Then choice questions were displayed, such as “Generally, where is A from B?” with the choices, “North, South, East and West”. Subjects were required to choose one answer. The dependent variables were the accuracy and response latency recorded automatically by computer upon the completion of each question.

Procedure

Subjects were randomly assigned to one of ten subgroups (five perspectives × two rooms) with an equal number of subjects in each group. The number of males and females was balanced in each group. Subjects were first informed the purpose and the content of the experiment. After signing a consent form, they underwent the following three phases of the experiment.

Screening phase. In order to screen out subjects with poor memory, subjects first took a test of memory. They were required to scan nine objects printed on a paper for 30 s and then generate these objects at the corresponding positions on a blank paper of the same size. These nine objects were not used in the following learning phase. Subjects who correctly recalled more than five objects were allowed to proceed to the next phase. All subjects could recall more than six objects in this test.

Learning phase. Subjects observed the nine experimental objects (including missile model, teapot, hammer, penguin toy, stoneware, flowerpot, lamp, chair, and pillar) printed as 3D objects on another paper. After they were familiar with the objects and could associate each with a unique name, they wore the HMD and watched an empty virtual room with the same size as the experimental room. This helped subjects adapt to the HMD and the simulated view. Next, the experimental virtual room, rectangular or cylindrical, and the nine experimental objects were displayed with one of the five perspectives. Subjects were given two minutes to learn the locations of objects in the virtual room and the experimenter helped them to recognize the virtual objects during this time.

Test phase. Subjects removed the HMD and started performing the egocentric pointing task and the world-reference task. When performing each spatial task, they received two practice trials similar to the formal tasks. The result of the practice trial was not considered in the final analysis. After understanding the requirements of each task, they performed the formal tasks. The total experiment time was around 1 h.

Results

All data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) to examine the effect of perspective elevation and room geometry on the performance in the egocentric pointing task and the world-referenced task.

The egocentric pointing task

Because the egocentric pointing task could not be completed under the 90° condition, only data obtained at 0°, 30°, 45°, and 60° angles were analyzed. Regarding the judgment of vertical direction, the main effect of perspective elevation was significant, F(3,40) = 8.28, p < .01. Multiple comparisons (using LSD method) showed that there was no significant difference among the judgments at 0°, 30°, 45°, while the mean angular errors at these three angles were smaller than at 60° (see Fig. 4). Neither the main effect of the room geometry, F(1,40) = .13, p = .716, nor the interaction effect between the room geometry and the perspective elevation, F(3,40) = .595, p = .622, was significant.

Regarding the judgment of horizontal direction, as depicted in Fig. 5, the interaction effect between the room geometry and the perspective elevation was significant, F(3,40) = 3.23, p = .032. Neither the main effect of the room geometry, F(1,40) = .94, p = .338, nor the main effect of perspective elevation, F(3,40) = 1.92, p = .142, was significant. In order to explain the two-way interaction, ANOVA was further conducted under each room. The effect of perspective elevation in the rectangular room was significant, F(3,20) = 3.65, p = .03, and the mean error was significantly greater at 0° than at 45°. The effect of perspective elevation was not observed in the cylindrical room.

There was a marginally significant effect of room geometry on the response latency, F(1,40) = 4.04, p = .05, reflecting that subjects spent longer time on judging directions in the rectangular room than in the cylindrical room. The main effect of perspective elevation, F(3,40) = 1.45, p = .242, and the interaction effect between the room geometry and the perspective elevation, F(3,40) = .358, p = .784, were not observed.

The world-referenced task

Data obtained at all five angles (perspectives) in the two rooms were analyzed in word-referenced task. Figure 6 plots the correct rates in this task. Neither the main effect of room geometry, F(1,50) = .19, p = .669, nor the interaction effect between perspective elevation and room geometry, F(4,50) = .34, p = .852, was significant. However, the main effect of perspective elevation was significant, F(4,50) = 2.67, p = .043, with the highest correct rate obtained at the 45° perspective. Further multiple comparisons (using LSD method) showed that the accuracy was significantly greater at 0° than at 90°; moreover, the accuracy was significantly greater at 45° than at 30°and 90°. There was no significant effect on response latency in this task.

Discussion

The goal of the present study was to determine the impact of perspective elevation and room geometry on mental representation in a virtual room space. Three findings are worthy to be emphasized. First, perspective elevation influenced the judgment of directions along the vertical dimension and also global situation awareness. With increasing perspective elevation, subjects made more errors in judging vertical directions with respect to the egocentric reference. The effect of perspective elevation on global situation awareness was more complex: the awareness changed nonlinearly between 0°and 45°, but decreased linearly between 45° and 90°. The best performance was found in the mid-elevation perspective (45°), which was consistent with a previous study (Wickens and Prevett 1995). Second, perspective elevation had a significant effect on the judgment of horizontal direction in the rectangular room but not in the cylindrical room, with greater angular errors at 0° than at 45°. Third, room geometry affected the time that subjects took to retrieve the egocentric information: in the egocentric pointing task, subjects made judgment of direction more quickly in the cylindrical room than in the rectangular room.

The effect of perspective elevation on the mental representation of spatial layout was evidenced by the error trend in judging vertical directions in this study. When the perspective elevates, people need to reconstruct the vertical dimension mentally in order to make spatial judgments along that dimension. As noted by Hendrix and Barfield (1997), people must determine the scale for the vertical information and rely on spatial cues to determine the vertical height. As the perspective elevates, the view of the room space provides fewer cues useful to recover vertical information. For an extreme example, when the perspective is vertical to the floor, a vertical line may appear to be a point. In order to recover vertical information, people may turn to other less efficient cues, such as the boundary line of the floor. Thus, the task of extracting vertical information from the scene is more dependent on the cognitive process than on the spatial process. Additional cognitive process may result in less accuracy in recovering spatial information. In other words, the additional cognitive process resulting from perspective elevation influences the efficiency of the frame of reference with respect to which spatial vertical information is represented in memory. This finding can partially explain why it was difficult for two operators in Schafer and Bowman (2004) study to collaborate in order to move the object in a virtual room. In their study, one operator watched the spatial layout through the route perspective and another through the oblique perspective. The latter might poorly understand the movement on the vertical plane. Thus, the two collaborators did not acquire the equal mental representation of the space.

Room geometry and perspective elevation interacted to influence the mental representation of the spatial horizontal information: the significant effect of perspective elevation was observed only in the rectangular room but not in the cylindrical room. This supported the finding in a previous study that the ecologically valid features, such as the structural characteristics provided by the rectangular shape of room, could influence the mental representation of spatial layout within the room (Colle and Reid 2003). Room geometry also influenced the time subjects took to perform the pointing task. Subjects responded faster in the cylindrical room than in the rectangular room. The data revealed the competition of references which people employed to code and interpret spatial relations (Carlson 1999). The objects inside and outside the layout serve as references that affect the accuracy of location in memory, while objects inside the layout serve as better reference (McNamara 2003). The walls outside the layout in the rectangular room had ecologically valid features (Colle and Reid 2003), such as the straight line and the orthogonal angle, and defined salient room axes to serve as references competing with references provided by objects inside the layout. There was less such competition in the cylindrical room, because the cylindrical wall had weak ecologically valid structural features. The strong competition between references in the rectangular room added to the effect of perspective elevation on the judgment of horizontal direction, and leaded more difficulty to construct the mental representation of spatial layout in the rectangular room than in the cylindrical room. It should be noted that in the present study the competition between references provided by the objects inside and outside the layout could be influenced by HMD, which might also provide a frame of reference to affect attention to spatial information inside the virtual room and decrease the reality of objects’ image (Wickens et al. 2005).

The findings of the present study are important for designing virtual environments. First, when the route, oblique, and aerial perspectives are considered in the design of virtual environments, spatial cues should be provided to compensate for the loss of spatial information in each perspective. For example, when a user observes spatial layout in virtual environment from an external viewpoint, adequate depth cues (Morar et al. 2002) should be provided to help the user to determine the relative height between him and spatial layout. Actually, in Schafer and Bowman’s study (2004), it was found that additional spatial cues were useful improve the collaboration between the two operators in moving objects in a virtual room.

Second, maps that display spatial layout from the oblique perspective (especially 45°) can assist navigation in virtual building. Traditional maps, like the “you-are-here” (YAH) map (Sayers et al. 2004), always depict the space from the aerial perspective. While this method reflects a great deal of insight into the mechanism of assisting the navigation, these maps lose spatial vertical relations within the space. The spatial knowledge acquired from the 45° perspective appears to be best for developing global situation awareness, which suggests that users assisted by a map with the 45° perspective can most easily figure out their direction to the target location.

Third, when designing virtual environments for training, designers should consider the effect of room geometry on spatial learning. The present study suggests that rectangular walls with ecologically valid structural features can negatively influence the mental representation of the spatial layout inside the virtual room. Thus, when a virtual room is the training environment, wall geometry should be one factor to be considered to facilitate spatial learning inside this virtual room.

Conclusion and future work

This study investigated the effects of perspective elevation and room geometry on mental representation of virtual rooms. It was found that the perspective-dependent representation was constructed when the perspective elevated in a virtual room space. Room geometry not only influenced the time used to perform spatial task but also interacted with the perspective elevation to influence the mental representation of spatial horizontal information.

This study reveals that the route, oblique and aerial perspectives lead to the acquisition of different spatial knowledge of the same virtual room space. Our present work aims to examine how people develop spatial knowledge when traveling vertically in virtual environment. For instance, if the perspective elevates continually along the vertical dimension of room, mental representation of this virtual room space will update dynamically, which allows for better understanding of the whole spatial characteristics of the room than any fixed perspective.
